title: The Elegant Math Behind Machine Learning
note: A stunning and accessible look at how machine learning emerges from linear algebra and optimization.

title: Lecture: Mathematics of Big Data and Machine Learning
note: MIT OpenCourseWare brings deep insight into how data becomes intelligence. A classic foundational view from academia.

title: Mental Models for AI: Patterns, Not Magic
note: A gentle 10-min intro to how AI builds on pattern recognition. You don't need to be technical to understand this mindset.

title: How To Learn Math for Machine Learning FAST (Even With Zero)
note: A self‑taught path into applied math for ML—from someone who dropped out of high school to working at Amazon.

title: Mathematics for Machine Learning [Full Course]
note: A full‑course introduction to the math behind ML—linear algebra, probability, and more.

title: Learn About Patterns for Kids with Cars, Trucks and Trains
note: A gentle exploration of pattern‑finding in everyday life—simple yet profound.

title: Machine learning and AI is extremely easy if you learn the math
note: Machine learning often comes down to simple equations. For example: y = mx + b — this line helps a machine guess values. The video shows how models use basic algebra to 'draw' predictions from data.

title: Here’s the Best Math Resources you need for AI and ML
note: This is like a roadmap for learning AI math. It starts with numbers and shapes — vectors (like arrows in space), and matrices (grids of numbers). A matrix multiplies like: [[1,2],[3,4]] x [5,6] → patterns begin forming.

title: 3Blue1Brown – The Math You Need For AI/ML
note: Visual math that feels like art. It explains how machines 'see' using dots and directions. Example: A dot product measures alignment — if two arrows point the same way, the result is big. That’s how AI sees patterns.

title: AI Explained: It's maths, not magic
note: AI is built on repetition and rules. A machine adjusts numbers over and over, like solving 2x + 3 = 7 again and again for millions of rows. This video shows how those rules let computers learn — one tiny step at a time.
